unnormalised: New Delhi Grapples with Deteriorating Air Quality Post-Diwali
normalised: New Delhi Grapples with Deteriorating Air Quality Post-Diwali

unnormalised: New Delhi, November 7, 2024 – Air quality in the National Capital Territory has plummeted to hazardous levels in the days following the Diwali festival, prompting renewed concerns from environmental agencies. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) reported an average Air Quality Index (AQI) exceeding 450 in several areas, categorized as "Severe".
normalised: New Delhi, seventh november two thousand and twenty four – Air quality in the National Capital Territory has plummeted to hazardous levels in the days following the Diwali festival, prompting renewed concerns from environmental agencies. The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) reported an average Air Quality Index (A Q I) exceeding four hundred and fifty in several areas, categorized as "Severe".

unnormalised: The sharp decline is attributed to a combination of factors including firecracker emissions, stubble burning in neighboring states like Haryana and Punjab, and unfavorable meteorological conditions. Particulate matter, particularly PM2.5 and PM10, has surged, posing significant health risks, especially for vulnerable populations.

Particulate matter, particularly P M two point five and P M ten, has surged, posing significant health risks, especially for vulnerable populations.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma, a senior pulmonologist at AIIMS, cautioned against prolonged outdoor exposure, recommending the use of N95 masks. The Delhi government has announced measures including increased water sprinkling and intensified monitoring of industrial emissions.
normalised: Doctor Sharma, a senior pulmonologist at A I I M S, cautioned against prolonged outdoor exposure, recommending the use of N ninety five masks. The Delhi government has announced measures including increased water sprinkling and intensified monitoring of industrial emissions.

unnormalised: Experts are also advocating for a transition to cleaner fuel alternatives and promoting eco-friendly celebrations during festivals. The situation highlights the ongoing challenge of balancing cultural traditions with environmental sustainability in India. The taste of festive biryani this year came with a side of smog, reminding everyone of the urgent need for cleaner air. Efforts are underway to mitigate the pollution, but a collective responsibility is crucial.
